Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Testing mechanisms for star formation via supercomputer simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The problem of how stars form is one of the key questions in modern astrophysics, with the evolution of the universe, structure of galaxies, and creation of planetary systems all inextricably tied to star formation. All current star formation exists within giant molecular clouds (GMCs)-the coldest, densest regions of the interstellar medium, but the initial conditions and specific process through which this occurs are still uncertain. One theory posits that the dominant mechanism for star formation is through triggering via collisions between GMCs. This project will test the cloud-collision theory by creating detailed numerical simulations to investigate GMC interactions. Regions of interstellar gas, hundreds of light-years across, will be evolved over millions of years using supercomputers. The resulting structures will be analyzed in detail to determine the likelihood of stars forming. The research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Fumitaka Nakamura, an expert in both star formation theory and numerical simulation, at the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan.

This project will be the first to rigorously implement supersonic turbulence, magnetic fields, and complex thermo-chemical functions in order to create the most realistic model of GMCs thus far. The numerical methods utilized to evolve the clouds will be magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) with adaptive mesh refinement (AMR). A state-of-the-art thermo-chemical function will also provide diagnostics to compare with observations. Clump-finding algorithms and virial analysis will be used to determine the ability of cloud collisions to compress material and initiate collapse into stars. Various parameters will be explored, including magnetic field strength and orientation, as well as collision velocity and turbulent power spectra. This research will not only further development of advanced numerical methods, but determine the importance of a potentially vital mechanism "cloud collisions" in the star formation process. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The precise mechanism for star and star cluster formation in relation to galactic environment is an important question in astrophysics, and one that is not well understood. Stars form in giant molecular clouds (GMCs), but at very low efficiencies—except in highly clustered, localized regions. Recent studies suggest that magnetic fields and turbulence in the interstellar gas may play significant roles in the formation of stars, limiting overall efficiency. Further, interactions or collisions between GMCs have been predicted to create shocks and cause localized regions to become gravitationally unstable. No previous study has implemented the combined effects of cloud collisions, turbulence, and magnetic fields.

Through the support of the NSF EAPSI program, the PI was given the opportunity to collaborate with Dr. Fumitaka Nakamura, an expert in numerical simulations and observations of star forming regions, at the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan (NAOJ). Under the guidance of Dr. Nakamura, the PI was able to initialize, test, and complete numerical simulations of magnetized, turbulent GMC collisions. Each additional physical process required substantial calculation, coding, and comparison with analytic models. This initial project involved running suites of magnetohydrodynamics simulations on supercomputers, exploring the dynamical effects of magnetic field strength and orientation, along with various levels of turbulence, comparing non-colliding and colliding GMCs. These types of simulations created dense clumps and filaments—potential star-forming regions. Preliminary analysis methods were developed as well, studying various density, velocity, and morphological properties of these structures. 

These findings were presented by the PI at a colloquium at NAOJ and a conference in Charleston, VA (“Filamentary Structure in Molecular Clouds”) and by the host advisor at star formation conferences in Denmark and the Netherlands (“The Early Life of Stellar Clusters: Formation and Dynamics” and “Star Formation Across Space and Time”). Collaboration is still ongoing, as a manuscript detailing these findings is in preparation, with planned scientific journal submission. An additional study with higher resolution simulations and comparison to observational results is subsequently planned. The opportunity provided by the EAPSI program was invaluable, as it fostered international collaboration and interaction, cultural exchange, and unique professional development.
